title: 103_hr113
content: The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" aims to boost economic growth by offering a temporary tax credit to encourage the purchase of new domestic passenger vehicles. This credit allows purchasers to reduce the vehicle's purchase price by assigning the credit in exchange. The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" offers a tax credit to individuals purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles. The credit is a percentage of the vehicle's purchase price, with limits based on the year of purchase. The credit amount cannot exceed $2,000 for taxable years ending on or before December 31, 1993, and $1,000 for years after that. Additionally, the credit can be assigned under regulations set by the Secretary. The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" provides a tax credit for purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles. The credit amount is $2,000 for taxable years ending on or before December 31, 1993, and $1,000 for years after that. Individuals can assign the credit to the dealer or manufacturer, who can then use it against their tax liability. The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" offers a tax credit for buying new domestic passenger vehicles. A new domestic passenger vehicle is defined as a vehicle purchased in its first retail sale that is produced by a domestic manufacturer in the US or Canada. The manufacturer must include specific information on the vehicle label to qualify for the credit. The Disclosure Act requires information on whether a vehicle is domestic and the percentage of parts from domestic manufacturers. A domestic vehicle manufacturer is defined as one with manufacturing facilities in the US producing vehicles for sale or export. The Disclosure Act defines a domestic vehicle manufacturer as having manufacturing facilities in the US producing vehicles for interstate sale or export, using 60% or more domestic motor vehicle parts. A domestic parts manufacturer is a manufacturer with facilities in the US or Canada that is not a related source. A domestic motor vehicle parts manufacturer must have facilities in the US or Canada and can utilize materials from related sources up to 25% of total production value. A domestic motor vehicle parts manufacturer can use components from related sources, not exceeding 25% of total production value. Related sources include natural persons who are Japanese citizens or entities owned or controlled by Japanese citizens. A domestic parts manufacturer in Japan can use components from related sources, such as entities owned or controlled by Japanese citizens, as long as they do not exceed 25% of the total production value. Ownership or control is defined as holding at least 50% of the capital structure of the entity. In the context of domestic parts manufacturing regulations in Japan, a related source is considered affiliated if they hold at least 2.5% but less than 50% of the capital structure of the entity, depending on the type of legal entity. In Japan, a related source is considered affiliated if they hold at least 2.5% but less than 50% of the capital structure of the entity. Purchase price and value definitions are provided for materials and components used in motor vehicle production. The manufacturer of parts or vehicles is determined for applying this title, including related sources and entities. The term 'United States' includes Puerto Rico and US possessions. Regulations must be prescribed within 60 days to carry out the section's purposes. The section does not apply to vehicles purchased after December 31, 1994. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to new domestic passenger vehicles purchased after December 31, 1992.
